author: timbeiko
content: I think the core of the problem is that various core developers (and parts of the community!) disagree about whether ASICs are good or bad, which makes it ~impossible to get to consensus, and it seems like everyone favours "not splitting the network" more than their preferred outcome on the anti-ASIC EIPs. We had a long AllCoreDevs call about this early march 2020, and I think a lot of the sentiment expressed there is probably still accurate. Also, with The Merge coming, it just doesn't make sense to spend time working on tweaking the PoW algorithm.

author: bridge-bot
content:
<dankrad> Here is the full reason why ASICs are more secure: They are essentially a form of proof of stake.
As Tim Beiko has remarked above, if you can't use them anymore, they become worthless, unlike GPUs, which still have other purposes and therefore remain valuable. But there's a deeper reason: When ASICs decide to attack, it's actually not very likely that the value of the chain goes to zero. If you look at past attacks, that's never how it bears out, often the drop is actually surprisingly small. However, the developers and users of the chain will probably change the hashing algorithm since current ASIC miners cannot be trusted, and so the ASICs still become worthless.
For GPU miners, you can't do this: The same GPUs can still be used for the new mining algorithm. 
So in essence, it's a bit like proof of stake, in that you can "slash" an attacker and take away their investment â€” but this only works with ASICs, which are specific to the algorithm, and not with GPUs

author: timbeiko
content:
We can't differentiate between GPUs and ASICs during the merge, so we need to plan for reasonably likely scenarios of miner collusion, and already are. There are some edge cases where miners could cause damage but it's too complicated to prevent at the protocol level, so in that case the solution is "social coordination" (i.e. we all agree that X is the last PoW block and hardcode it in clients). I think we probably want to make this explicit in the transition spec somewhere. 

Also, it's worth noting that most chains that get attacked basically have no usage and likely aren't "priced" as secure. I suspect a serious attack on BTC or ETH would have a larger price impact than BSV or ETC given that the former are considered much more secure.
